elements.content: The coordination polymer {[Cu3(hbpdc)(OH)2(H2O)]·2H2O} n (1, hbpdc = 3,3′-dihydroxy-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylic anion) was prepared under hydrothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that complex 1 features a highly ordered 3D nanoporous structure encapsulating a zigzag water chain. Variable-temperature magnetic studies indicated the presence of strong antiferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: The coordination polymer {[Cu3(hbpdc)(OH)2(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (1, hbpdc = 3,3'-dihydroxy-2,2'-bipyridine-6,6'-dicarboxylic anion) was prepared under hydrothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that complex 1 features a highly ordered 3D nanoporous structure encapsulating a zigzag water chain. Variable-temperature magnetic studies indicated the presence of strong antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: The coordination polymer {[Cu3(hbpdc)(OH)2(H2O)]·2H2O} n (1, hbpdc = 3,3′-dihydroxy-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylic anion) was prepared under hydrothermal conditions. It features a highly ordered 3D nanoporous structure encapsulating a zigzag water chain, and the presence of strong antiferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: The coordination polymer {[Cu3(hbpdc)(OH)2(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (1, hbpdc = 3,3'-dihydroxy-2,2'-bipyridine-6,6'-dicarboxylic anion) was prepared under hydrothermal conditions. It features a highly ordered 3D nanoporous structure encapsulating a zigzag water chain, and the presence of strong antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: Recently, remarkable advances in the development of porous crystalline materials based on metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have produced various solids that display porous behavior. A successful strategy in synthesizing novel porous MOFs with unique structures and properties is hydrothermal/solvothermal synthesis by incorporating appropriate metal ions (connectors) with multifunctional bridging ligands (linkers). In this regard, the organic ligands play crucial roles in determining the resulted polymeric structures, because the change in the type of bridging units, the flexibility of the molecular backbone, and the conformational preference can lead to a remarkable class of materials bearing diverse architectures and impressive potential functions. On the other hand, hydrothermal in situ synthesis has been developed rapidly, not only for its advantage in the crystal engineering of complexes but also for possible application in organic syntheses. However, hydrothermal synthesis is a relatively complex process, and the final products under a given set of conditions are often unpredictable. Thus, the discovery of new hydrothermal in situ reactions is still a great challenge. In the ongoing quest for the design of novel porous materials, many chemists synthesize these complexes with a lot of different carboxylic acids, such as aromatic acids, aliphatic acids, and heterocyclic acids. On the basis of carboxylate linkers, it is noteworthy that a number of investigations have led to robust, thermally stable MOFs with large pores. However, compared to the rigid carboxylate ligands, the flexible ones have been investigated limitedly, owing to the difficulties in predicting the resulting architectures. In this context, we employ one binicotinic acid derivative 3,3′-dimethoxy-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylic acid (H2mbpdc), as flexible ligand, to construct metal−organic frameworks, based on the following considerations: (i) the flexible and multifunctional coordination sites may generate multidimensional structures; (ii) the H2mbpdc ligand was transformed in situ into 3,3′-dihydroxy-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylic acid (H4hbpdc) during the hydrothermal process, and this may be used as a deliberate strategy to produce unusual MOF architectures; (iii) compared with other binicotinic derivatives, the substituents at the 3,3′-positions were found to strongly effect the geometry and the energy of the bipyridine complexes, thus resulting in novel structures; (iv) until now, no such compound has been studied for its magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: Recently, remarkable advances in the development of porous crystalline materials based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have produced various solids that display porous behavior. A successful strategy in synthesizing novel porous MOFs with unique structures and properties is hydrothermal/solvothermal synthesis by incorporating appropriate metal ions (connectors) with multifunctional bridging ligands (linkers). In this regard, the organic ligands play crucial roles in determining the resulted polymeric structures, because the change in the type of bridging units, the flexibility of the molecular backbone, and the conformational preference can lead to a remarkable class of materials bearing diverse architectures and impressive potential functions. On the other hand, hydrothermal in situ synthesis has been developed rapidly, not only for its advantage in the crystal engineering of complexes but also for possible application in organic syntheses. However, hydrothermal synthesis is a relatively complex process, and the final products under a given set of conditions are often unpredictable. Thus, the discovery of new hydrothermal in situ reactions is still a great challenge. In the ongoing quest for the design of novel porous materials, many chemists synthesize these complexes with a lot of different carboxylic acids, such as aromatic acids, aliphatic acids, and heterocyclic acids. On the basis of carboxylate linkers, it is noteworthy that a number of investigations have led to robust, thermally stable MOFs with large pores. However, compared to the rigid carboxylate ligands, the flexible ones have been investigated limitedly, owing to the difficulties in predicting the resulting architectures. In this context, we employ one binicotinic acid derivative 3,3'-dimethoxy-2,2'-bipyridine-6,6'-dicarboxylic acid (H2mbpdc), as flexible ligand, to construct metal-organic frameworks, based on the following considerations: (i) the flexible and multifunctional coordination sites may generate multidimensional structures; (ii) the H2mbpdc ligand was transformed in situ into 3,3'-dihydroxy-2,2'-bipyridine-6,6'-dicarboxylic acid (H4hbpdc) during the hydrothermal process, and this may be used as a deliberate strategy to produce unusual MOF architectures; (iii) compared with other binicotinic derivatives, the substituents at the 3,3'-positions were found to strongly effect the geometry and the energy of the bipyridine complexes, thus resulting in novel structures; (iv) until now, no such compound has been studied for its magnetic properties.

elements.content: Functional groups (carboxyl and methoxyl) were successfully grafted onto the bipyridine backbone and gave one new binicotinic acid derivative, namely, 3,3′-dimethoxy-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylic acid (H2mbpdc) (see Scheme 1 in the ). Under hydrothermal conditions, the crystalline compounds (1) were successfully obtained by the reaction of H2mbpdc with Cu(CH3COO)2 ·4H2O and characterized as having the formulas ({[Cu3(hbpdc)(OH)2(H2O)]·2H2O} n ), based on elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The structural analysis indicates that 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c (number 128) and demethylation of the H2mbpdc ligand occurs in the process of the formation of 1. We reasoned the mechanism for the demethylation to be as follows: the Cu2+ atom is coordinated to the O atom of the methoxy, which weakened the bond energy of C−O, and the high temperature and pressure may be used as effective reaction conditions to promote the demethylation. In the crystal structure, complex 1 features a highly ordered 3D nanoporous structure encapsulating a zigzag water chain. There are two crystallographically independent copper centers with different coordination modes in each asymmetric unit. As shown in Figure a, the coordination polyhedron around the Cu1 atom is a pentacoordinated, slightly distorted square pyramid. The basal plane is defined by one pyridine nitrogen, one carboxylic oxygen, and two hydroxyl oxygens, while the apical site is occupied by one water oxygen. The coordination polyhedron around copper atom Cu2 displays a heptacoordinated capped octahedron. The octahedron is defined by four hydroxyl oxygen atoms, one oxygen atom of water, and one bridging O from the hbpdc ligand. The capping ligating atom is the bridging O atom from another hbpdc ligand. Within the assembly, each hbpdc anion has an identical coordination mode, chelated to two Cu atoms and linked to two Cu atoms, exhibiting a bis(chelating−bridging tetradentate) coordination feature (Scheme 2 in the ). The adjacent Cu atoms are connected by carboxyl bridges, and most importantly, the coordination water molecules and the hydroxyl groups also bridge the Cu-OCO-Cu unit, which assembles into the highly ordered 3D structure with a regular square channel of about 11.53 × 11.53 Å2 (defined by the separation between the Cu2A and Cu2H) (Figure b). This section of nanopores possesses C 2 symmetry and displays a dodecanuclear metallic macrocycle of Cu12C48N8O28, in which the arrangement of 12 Cu atoms is significantly different from the coplanar organization previously reported, which is not truly coplanar. Remarkably, the lattice water molecules (O3 and its symmetry related atoms) form a zigzag water chain through hydrogen bonding interactions (Table S2 of the ), located in the nanopores (Figure S1 of the ), with each water molecule acting as both single hydrogen bonding donor and acceptor (Figure c). When the lattice water molecules were removed, the effective void space is calculated by the PLATON program as being 12.3% of the crystal volume (183.6 Å3 out of the 1495.0 Å3 unit cell volume). It is worth noting that the flexible joint, the central C−C bond, and the introduction of the hydroxyl groups play a vital role in the formation of this 3D nanoporous structure. The change of dihedral angles can be accomplished through the rotation of the central C−C bond, which is responsible for the formation of the wall of the porous, square backbone.

Under hydrothermal conditions, the crystalline compounds (1) were successfully obtained by the reaction of H2mbpdc with Cu(CH3COO)2 ⋅4H2O and characterized as having the formulas ({[Cu3(hbpdc)(OH)2(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n ), based on elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The structural analysis indicates that 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c (number 128) and demethylation of the H2mbpdc ligand occurs in the process of the formation of 1. We reasoned the mechanism for the demethylation to be as follows: the Cu2+ atom is coordinated to the O atom of the methoxy, which weakened the bond energy of C-O, and the high temperature and pressure may be used as effective reaction conditions to promote the demethylation. In the crystal structure, complex 1 features a highly ordered 3D nanoporous structure encapsulating a zigzag water chain. The basal plane is defined by one pyridine nitrogen, one carboxylic oxygen, and two hydroxyl oxygens, while the apical site is occupied by one water oxygen. The coordination polyhedron around copper atom Cu2 displays a heptacoordinated capped octahedron. The octahedron is defined by four hydroxyl oxygen atoms, one oxygen atom of water, and one bridging O from the hbpdc ligand. The capping ligating atom is the bridging O atom from another hbpdc ligand. Within the assembly, each hbpdc anion has an identical coordination mode, chelated to two Cu atoms and linked to two Cu atoms, exhibiting a bis(chelating-bridging tetradentate) coordination feature (Scheme 2 in the ). The change of dihedral angles can be accomplished through the rotation of the central C-C bond, which is responsible for the formation of the wall of the porous, square backbone.

elements.content: (a) View of the connectivity of 1. Symmetry codes: (A) −x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, −z + 1; (B) x, −y, z + 1/2; (C) −x, −y, −z; (D) −x, y, −z + 1/2; (E) −x, −y, −z + 1. (b) The 3D MOFs with 1D channels that are filled with zigzag water chains along the c axis. (c) View of the zigzag arrangement of the water molecules along the a axis. The yellow dashed lines indicate the hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of the connectivity of 1. Symmetry codes: (A) -x + 1/2, -y + 1/2, -z + 1; (B) x, -y, z + 1/2; (C) -x, -y, -z; (D) -x, y, -z + 1/2; (E) -x, -y, -z + 1. (b) The 3D MOFs with 1D channels that are filled with zigzag water chains along the c axis. (c) View of the zigzag arrangement of the water molecules along the a axis. The yellow dashed lines indicate the hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 reveals that the first weight lost is 3.53% in the range from 30 to 140 °C, corresponding to the removal of guest water molecules (calcd for 1·2H2O: 3.38%), followed by weight loss of 1.78% in the range of 140−260 °C, consistent with the removal of coordination water molecules (1.69% calcd). Compound 1 does not decompose until 450 °C (Figure S2 in the ), which indicates the high thermal stability of its three-dimensional network. In order to confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials, as well as evaluate the structural information during the removal of lattice water molecules, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was carried out. Although the experimental patterns (Figure S3 in the ) have a few unindexed diffractions in comparison with that simulated from the single-crystal model, it can still be well considered that the bulk synthesized material and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous, and the integrity of the 3D framework is robust to the exclusion of water.
elements.clean_text: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 reveals that the first weight lost is 3.53% in the range from 30 to 140 °C, corresponding to the removal of guest water molecules (calcd for 1⋅2H2O: 3.38%), followed by weight loss of 1.78% in the range of 140-260 °C, consistent with the removal of coordination water molecules (1.69% calcd). Compound 1 does not decompose until 450 °C (Figure S2 in the ), which indicates the high thermal stability of its three-dimensional network. In order to confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials, as well as evaluate the structural information during the removal of lattice water molecules, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was carried out. Although the experimental patterns (Figure S3 in the ) have a few unindexed diffractions in comparison with that simulated from the single-crystal model, it can still be well considered that the bulk synthesized material and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous, and the integrity of the 3D framework is robust to the exclusion of water.

elements.content: The temperature dependent molar magnetic susceptibilities of 1 were measured in the 2−300 K temperature range and shown as χM T and χM versus T plots in Figure . The experimental χM T value of 1 at room temperature is 0.79 cm3 K mol−1, lower than the caculated spin-only value 1.125 cm3 K mol−1 with three Cu2+ ions, indicating an appreciable antiferromagnetic exchange between the magnetic centers. Upon cooling, the χM T value declines and reaches 0.016 cm3 K mol−1 at 2.0 K. The χM value increases continuously on cooling from room temperature until approaching a maximum of 0.007 cm3 K mol−1 at 18 K. It then decreases quickly to a minimum value of 0.005 cm3 K mol−1 at 6 K, below which the χM value of 1 increases again. The maximum appearing in the χM vs T curve indicates a significant antiferromagnetic couple between Cu2+ ions through μ-O bridges. The upturn around 6 K is the possible behavior for an antiferromagnetically coupled system with the presence of a small amount of paramagnetic impurities.
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependent molar magnetic susceptibilities of 1 were measured in the 2-300 K temperature range and shown as χM T and χM versus T plots in Figure . The experimental χM T value of 1 at room temperature is 0.79 cm3 K mol-1, lower than the caculated spin-only value 1.125 cm3 K mol-1 with three Cu2+ ions, indicating an appreciable antiferromagnetic exchange between the magnetic centers. Upon cooling, the χM T value declines and reaches 0.016 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K. The χM value increases continuously on cooling from room temperature until approaching a maximum of 0.007 cm3 K mol-1 at 18 K. It then decreases quickly to a minimum value of 0.005 cm3 K mol-1 at 6 K, below which the χM value of 1 increases again. The maximum appearing in the χM vs T curve indicates a significant antiferromagnetic couple between Cu2+ ions through μ-O bridges. The upturn around 6 K is the possible behavior for an antiferromagnetically coupled system with the presence of a small amount of paramagnetic impurities.

elements.content: The strong antiferromagnetic exchange is also confirmed by a negative Weiss constant (θ = −169 K) determined by the data in the temperature range 40−300 K (Figure ). It is interesting that the χM T curve shows a sigmoid shape in the temperature range 2−30 K, and the dχM T/dT versus T plot shows the transition at 16 K (the inset in Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The strong antiferromagnetic exchange is also confirmed by a negative Weiss constant (θ = -169 K) determined by the data in the temperature range 40-300 K (Figure ). It is interesting that the χM T curve shows a sigmoid shape in the temperature range 2-30 K, and the dχM T/dT versus T plot shows the transition at 16 K (the inset in Figure ).

elements.content: Since Cu2 atoms are bridged by μ2-O1 and μ3-O2 atoms forming the (Cu2O2) n chain, and the Cu2Cu2A distance is 2.943 Å, while Cu1 and Cu2 are bridged by μ3-O2 atoms, and the Cu1Cu2 distance is 3.276 Å, complex 1 can be considered an antiferromagnetic one-dimensional copper chain model with H = −J∑S Ai S A i+1 , incorporating the contribution of two paramagnetic Cu2+. The final expression of this model is χ chain = N g 2 β 2 k T ( 0.25 + 0.074975 x + 0.075235 x 2 1 + 0.9931 x + 0.172135 x 2 + 0.75825 x 3 ) x = | J | / k T χ′ = χ chain + 2 χ Cu χ Cu = N g 2 β 2 3 k T [ S ( S + 1 ) ] χ = χ′ / [ 1 − ( 2 z J / N g 2 β 2 ) χ′ ] where N, g, β, and k have their usual meanings. zJ accounts for the Cu1−Cu2 and interchain interactions. The least-squares analysis of magnetic susceptibilities data above 40 K led to J = −128 cm−1, zJ = −94, g = 2.02, and R = 6 × 10−6 for 1.

The final expression of this model is    χ   chain   =   N   g   2     β   2     k T    (   0.25 + 0.074975 x + 0.075235   x   2     1 + 0.9931 x + 0.172135   x   2   + 0.75825   x   3     )      x = | J | / k T     χ' =   χ   chain   + 2   χ   Cu         χ   Cu   =   N   g   2     β   2     3 k T   [ S ( S + 1 ) ]     χ = χ' / [ 1 - ( 2 z J / N   g   2     β   2   ) χ' ]  where N, g, β, and k have their usual meanings. zJ accounts for the Cu1-Cu2 and interchain interactions. The least-squares analysis of magnetic susceptibilities data above 40 K led to J = -128 cm-1, zJ = -94, g = 2.02, and R = 6 × 10-6 for 1.

elements.content: In summary, we designed, synthesized, and investigated the self-assembly properties of a novel flexible binicotinic derivative with two hydroxyl groups. The present result reveals the 3,3′-dihydroxy-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylic ligand plays crucial roles in determining the highly ordered 3D nanoporous structure of 1, due to its diversity coordination sites and special bridge modes. Furthermore, the magnetic measurement suggests the significant antiferromagnetic interactions between copper atoms, but at present, as discussed above, it is still difficult to simulate it by a suitable magnetic model. Thereby, the further exploration of the magnetic properties of compound 1 will be our follow-up work.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we designed, synthesized, and investigated the self-assembly properties of a novel flexible binicotinic derivative with two hydroxyl groups. The present result reveals the 3,3'-dihydroxy-2,2'-bipyridine-6,6'-dicarboxylic ligand plays crucial roles in determining the highly ordered 3D nanoporous structure of 1, due to its diversity coordination sites and special bridge modes. Furthermore, the magnetic measurement suggests the significant antiferromagnetic interactions between copper atoms, but at present, as discussed above, it is still difficult to simulate it by a suitable magnetic model. Thereby, the further exploration of the magnetic properties of compound 1 will be our follow-up work.

elements.content: Experimental synthesis, crystallographic data of 1 in CIF format, TGA patterns, table of crystallographic data, and additional figures (PDF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Experimental synthesis, crystallographic data of 1 in CIF format, TGA patterns, table of crystallographic data, and additional figures (PDF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 reveals that the first weight lost is 3.53% in the range from 30 to 140 °C, corresponding to the removal of guest water molecules (calcd for 1·2H2O: 3.38%), followed by weight loss of 1.78% in the range of 140−260 °C, consistent with the removal of coordination water molecules (1.69% calcd). Compound 1 does not decompose until 450 °C (Figure S2 in the ), which indicates the high thermal stability of its three-dimensional network. In order to confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials, as well as evaluate the structural information during the removal of lattice water molecules, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was carried out. Although the experimental patterns (Figure S3 in the ) have a few unindexed diffractions in comparison with that simulated from the single-crystal model, it can still be well considered that the bulk synthesized material and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous, and the integrity of the 3D framework is robust to the exclusion of water.

Compound 1 does not decompose until 450 °C (Figure S2 in the ), which indicates the high thermal stability of its three-dimensional network. In order to confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials, as well as evaluate the structural information during the removal of lattice water molecules, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was carried out. Although the experimental patterns (Figure S3 in the ) have a few unindexed diffractions in comparison with that simulated from the single-crystal model, it can still be well considered that the bulk synthesized material and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous, and the integrity of the 3D framework is robust to the exclusion of water.

metadata.title: A Novel 3D Porous Cu(II)-Based Metal−Organic Framework Built from H4hbpdc Ligand: Synthesis, Structure, and Magnetic Characterization (H4hbpdc = 3,3′-Dihydroxy-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylic)
